data.text: Washing Clothes while Bike Touring: Laundromats?
Washing clothes while touring‚Ä¶.do you use laundromats, hotel/park/convenience store sinks? Does anyone use the Scrubba wash bag?
If I stay in a hotel I wash stuff while I‚Äôm showering, just put it on the cubicle floor, tread the muck out of it, rinse and dry
data.author: Keith Warner

data.text: I guess stepping on it is one way to do it, interesting.
data.author: Ed Chimahusky

data.text: Yes, all the above
data.author: Michael Viglianco

data.text: how would you rate the scuba? Does it live up to it‚Äôs name?
data.author: Ed Chimahusky

data.text: Well I just use a basic dry bag
data.author: Michael Viglianco

data.text: I have used a scrubber bag on my last 3 tours (each 2 to 3 months long). It is so much easier then washing clothes in tiny sinks. I just put in what the two of us were wearing that day, while I shower I agitate the bag with a foot. Rinse the same way then use towels, if staying somewhere, the squeeze out the clothes. We carry a lightweight lune that doesn't need pegs to hang. Always dry by the morning
data.author: Sarah Wragge-Morley

data.text: what is a lune?
data.author: Ed Chimahusky

data.text: think they mean line as in washing line
data.author: Vicky Cowan

data.text: yes see comment from Vicky, she can read auto-corrected speak üòâ
data.author: Sarah Wragge-Morley

data.text: Pretty much any and all opportunities including ‚Äúshlaundry‚Äù - shower/laundry while showering. But, yeah, nothing better than that day when ALL the stuff gets cleaned in a real washer/dryer!
data.author: Russ McCoy

data.text: any sink with preferebly warm water and plain soap. Merino clothes, don¬¥t smell too much. Cycling baggy. Dries quickly.
data.author: Supp Suppinger

data.text: If in France all cemeteries have a tap
data.author: Vin Carter

data.text: I rinse things out in any sink. If there is none available, I put water and a blob of shampoo into one of my dry bags and swish things around it that. (NB: I use shampoo for me, my laundry and dishes when touring - saves carrying separate soaps etc.) I prefer to rinse things out every evening if possible, rather than waiting until I have no clean(ish) clothes left. tht keeps me from every having to work out how to dry a whole lot of stuff when the weather is bad. I have never used a laundromat when touring.
data.author: Biff Frederikson

data.text: Srubba bag $50. Large GREAT VALUE freezer bag 6¬¢. Sometimes used the $3 dry bag.
data.author: Tom Watson

data.text: Riding shorts get washed every night in the sink or shower. Almost every small town has a laundromat for the bulk of your clothes.
data.author: Fred Dixon

data.text: depends where. Not at all if we talk for example about Poland and the region. Still a few years ago we had .. 2-3 laundromat in the capital city Warsaw. In a small town forget it.
data.author: Ewa ≈öwiderska

data.text: I should have said 'in the U.S.'
data.author: Fred Dixon

data.text: Yeah, laundromats in Europe tend to harder to find than in the U.S. Just a few weeks back we tried to find one in a densely-populated part of Paris and only found one within a reasonable walking distance. That said, they are becoming more and more scarce in the U.S. as well it seems to me. That said, it is not uncommon for campgrounds and hotels to have them so the availability of one is certainly a factor you can use when deciding which hotel or campground to stay in on any given night. I'd certainly rather be in my room watching TV while my laundry is running than sitting on a hard plastic chair in a laundromat.
data.author: Justin Stephen

data.text: I was recently in Italy and to my surprise they are pretty much available everywhere. Good.
data.author: Ewa ≈öwiderska

data.text: I wash it wherever possible and dry it on my bicycle. Never needed a special bag. Living on the road for 8,5 years.
data.author: Ewa ≈öwiderska

data.text: ‚ÄúQuick way to dry‚Äù shorts etc (Medium size towel,) after your shower open towel then roll up with shorts/T/shirt.Twist both ends as much as you can. All water will go into towel.üëçJob done.üö¥üëç
data.author: Darrell Davis

data.text: Random sinks, showers and the occasional washing machine. I use Dr Bronners citrus.The citrus really breaks down the Chamois butter and sunscreen oils and I feel like it washes out thoroughly. That being said- I do look for opportunities to use a washing machine every once in a while. I feel like it helps with any possible soap build up and gives me a fresh start on all of my stuff. I usually wear my bathing suit and a jacket and throw everything else in- socks, cycling clothes, off the bike clothing...everything!
data.author: Cyndy Mansur

data.text:
I wear a little black dress on laundry day. Read all about ot here: https://www.adventurecycling.org/blog/hung-out-to-dry/
Hung Out to Dry
adventurecycling.org
data.author: Jessica Levine

data.text: I read your post about that a while ago. I think that's a great idea-Glad that you were able the figure out a way to get your stuff back that night!
data.author: Cyndy Mansur

data.text: We have the original scrubba for small items while caravanning and really like it. If you get the cammo version it has a larger valve so a bit quicker/user-friendly. It really just a dry bag with agitator-nipples üòÖ Many people in caravanning groups use wool wash as you don‚Äôt need to rinse it like normal detergent. I‚Äôve seen people strap dry bags to their front forks with the Blackburn Outpost Cargo Cage - I reckon that could work really well with a Scrubba as a mobile laundry?
data.author: Debra Baum

data.text: I‚Äôve done all those. Including first part of shower being clothes on. Sinks and shower are less effective for me. Laundromat most effective. I was given a large scrubba bag for a present before last year‚Äôs ~4300 mile tour. That proved to be the second best method after coin operated laundry. The bag doubles as a very durable stuff sack and the ‚Äúnubbins‚Äù inside really seem to help it clean better. I used the 3 minute wash and a couple of quick rinses. Like all ‚Äúnon-dryer‚Äù laundry, the wring out in a towel really helps it line dry.
data.author: Matthew Dickey

data.text: You don't need any of that....a small bit of soap, water, drybag and a towel to dry. Do a search for "Dry bag laundry technique". FYI, you don't need a special drybag designed for laundry...any drybag will do. For soap, I highly recommend Camp Sudz with Citronnela. Camp Sudz is good for body/hair/clothing/dishes and whatever you need to clean. Biodegradable/evironmentally friendly, effective with little water and used sparingly so a little bit goes a long way. Outside of washing clothes while out on a tour, it works great on beach clothes or if you go the pool at the hotel you're staying at so they're dry and you can pack them away to travel.
data.author: Josh Kebschull

data.text: Jacuzzi tub and expensive hotel room I'll try to find the picture!
data.author: Joanne Mitchell

data.text: Yes to all except the Scrubba. Depends on the tour and even sections of a tour. You wash how and where you can, laundromats and their power outlets are awesome, but not always around!
data.author: William Griggs

data.text:
A little laundry day story for all y'all: what to wear when it's all in there--https://www.adventurecycling.org/blog/hung-out-to-dry/
Hung Out to Dry
adventurecycling.org
data.author: Jessica Levine

data.text: When I don't have a sink, any dry bag will work like a scrubba. I use laundromats when they are handy, I use the sink at campgrounds or hotels when needed.
data.author: Jean Phillips

data.text: I wash them when I shower.
data.author: Sam Morris

data.text: ..shower day/laundry day
data.author: Michael J Lewis

data.text: Thanks for all the great input
data.author: Ed Chimahusky

data.text: Sinks and showers
data.author: Jeff Stone

data.text: All kinds of interesting methods. Good question. No matter what method you use to clean your riding clothes be sure to rinse them very carefully. The cleaning product can cause rashes and skin irritations.
data.author: Bill Heimann

data.text: I used a dry bag (actually it's a shower bag - a dry bag with a shower in one end - but any dry bag would work), or random bathroom sinks.
data.author: Leif Warner

data.text: No cotton takes too long to dry
data.author: Charles Nighbor

data.text: Keep in mind clothes are only full of sweat with body salts A clean rinse is all that is needed most of the time
data.author: Charles Nighbor

data.text: We take a shower with our clothes, then wash our bodies, rinse everything, then squeeze the clothes out in a towel. Hang them up overnight.
data.author: Patricia Roth

data.text: if it's a big enough shower I have been known to take the bike in there as well ... ergonomics ... üòâ
data.author: Stuart Mather

data.text: Depends on the tour. Some, I carry a full set of camp/town clothes and a second kit. Some, I just bring an extra set of shorts and socks. If it's the former extreme, laundromat or hotel washer/dryer or shower. If it's the latter, everything gets rinsed out in the hand pump at camp then hung on the hammock or tarp to dry overnight. Every three days or so it'll get actually washed in an hand sink or shower with unscented Dr. Bronner's.
data.author: John Almond

data.text: All of the above. Depends on where when and what is available. Wash out short nightly and lay them on the bike to dry then wear them the next day almost every day. Fresh socks daily with foot powder (old army thing). Dirty clothes go into a drybag or scrubba when I carry it, to keep the stink and whatever from everything else. Wash socks and shirt and canp clothes when socks get low in whatever is aroubd, scrubba, machine, semi truck tire, gravel road, whatever‚Ä¶.
data.author: Robert Neidlinger

data.text: Yep we use a scrubba. It is better than our washing machine. First choice is a washing machine at a friends or warm showers. Second choice especially for sweaty socks and undies is out scrubba.
data.author: Kel Fowler

data.text: Dry bag + water + soap + hand
data.author: Sue Sommers

data.text: Wash?
data.author: Jeff Neumann

data.author: Ed Chimahusky

New item by joanne mitchell

data.author: Joanne Mitchell

data.text: I wear my cycling kit in the shower and wash it as I take it off. I also bring laundry detergent impregnated sheets when I tour...they weigh nothing and pack small. Good luck!
data.author: Mike Schlacter

data.text: I take three changes of clothing, wash two in a laundromat every other day, unless Im crashing at a friends place, then I do all the laundry while borrowing an extra large t shirt
data.author: Chaya Kostelicki AU

data.text: Sink and/or shower. In the shower i do my body and the clothes at the same time.
data.author: Daniel Ellsworth

data.text: Yes. All the above.
data.author: Hank Rowe

data.text: I did the laundromat. Took it down to a t-shirt and shorts so I could get it all done at once . I mean, who cares, you're in a laundromat. Used the time to look at maps, write postcards, google stuff that needed to be googled. it was good down time. Plus downy fresh clothes are nice.
data.author: Christopher Lackner
